p: More interestingly, Amrouche et al. [ 18] investigated both in vitro and in a food system the antibacterial activity of T. satureioides EOs, extracted from the whole plant, against foodborne bacteria ( E. coli, S. aureus, and B. cereus). The paper disc diffusion and broth microdilution methods were used for the in vitro test and the beef minced meat was used as food model. Thereby, the addition of T. satureioides EOs to inoculated beef minced meat decreased the tested strain population after 4 days of storage. Moreover, in vitro investigations indicated that B. cereus was the most sensitive bacteria (Ф = 19 mm and MIC = 1.1%), followed by S. aureus (Ф = 16 mm, MIC = 1.1%) and then E. coli (Ф = 14.25 mm, MIC = 1.25%) [ 18].
